title: Random Circuit Sampling: Fourier Expansion and Statistics

sections.introduction:
The 2019 paper â€œQuantum supremacy using a programmable superconducting processorâ€  described an experiment carried out by Googleâ€™s Sycamore quantum computer.
Googleâ€™s Sycamore quantum computer performed a sampling task; that is,
it generated (with considerable noise) random bitstrings (vectors of zeroes and ones) of length nğ‘›n, 12â‰¤nâ‰¤5312ğ‘›5312\leq n\leq 53,
from certain discrete probability distributions supported on all such 2nsuperscript2ğ‘›2^{n} bitstrings.
Googleâ€™s sampling task is referred to as random circuit sampling (RCS). The samples are from probability distributions that depend on the circuits (a circuit can be regarded as a program that the quantum computer runs); These probability distributions are not computed by the quantum computers, and for large number of qubits their computation is claimed to be infeasible (even for a quantum computer).
In the Google experiment the Sycamore quantum computer produced samples, each
consisting
of several hundred thousand binary strings (â€œbitstringsâ€), for each of around 1000 random circuits. For each sample, a certain statistic called the linear cross-entropy fidelity estimator denoted by â„±Xâ€‹Eâ€‹Bsubscriptâ„±ğ‘‹ğ¸ğµ{\mathcal{F}}_{XEB} (and sometimes simply by Xâ€‹Eâ€‹Bğ‘‹ğ¸ğµXEB) was computed. Based on the value of this estimator it was concluded that the samples produced by the quantum computer represent â€œquantum supremacy.â€ This paper continues our statistical analysis of the data and the statistical methods
of the Google experiment and may have wider interest for the study of NISQ computers. For our earlier works, see
 0 1. In this paper we rely, for the first time, on simulations for noisy quantum circuits, and for that purpose we used both the Google and the IBM simulators. (We also ran a few 5-qubit experiments on freely available IBM 7-qubit quantum computers.) All this experimental data and simulations are based on samples of N=500,000ğ‘500000N=500,000 bitstrings for every circuit that we study. In the appendix we also use our statistical tools to analyze samples for 12-qubit computation from a recent experiment  of logical circuits based on neutral atoms. The main novelty of this paper is the use of Fourier analysis (the Fourierâ€“Walsh expansion) for statistical analysis of samples coming from NISQ computers and from simulations and, in particular, to refine the â„±Xâ€‹Eâ€‹Bsubscriptâ„±ğ‘‹ğ¸ğµ{\cal F}_{XEB} fidelity estimator according to Fourier degrees. Put
[n]={1,2,â€¦,n}delimited-[]ğ‘›12â€¦ğ‘›[n]=\{1,2,\dots,n\}. Recall that every real function fğ‘“f defined on 0-1 vectors xğ‘¥x of length nğ‘›n, the Fourierâ€“Walsh expansion of fğ‘“f is a representation of fğ‘“f as a linear combination of the Fourierâ€“Walsh functions WSâ€‹(x)subscriptğ‘Šğ‘†ğ‘¥W_{S}(x), where Sğ‘†S goes over all subsets of [n]delimited-[]ğ‘›[n]. (See section 2.1 for details.)
The coefficients f^â€‹(S)^ğ‘“ğ‘†\widehat{f}(S) are referred to as the Fourierâ€“Walsh coefficients of fğ‘“f, and if k=|S|ğ‘˜ğ‘†k=|S| then f^â€‹(S)^ğ‘“ğ‘†\widehat{f}(S) is referred to as a degree-kğ‘˜k Fourierâ€“Walsh coefficient.
We use both analytical methods and simulations to study the effect of readout and gate errors on the refined Fourier-based estimators, and use this study to examine the data from the Google experiment and from simulations.
 For an early work on noise stability, noise sensitivity and Fourierâ€“Walsh expansion see Benjamini, Kalai, and Schramm .111The Fourierâ€“Walsh expansion is also related to the ANOVA decomposition in statistics that goes back to Hoeffding, see, e.g., 2. Kalai and Kindler  used a related noise operator based on
Fourierâ€“Hermite expansion
to study noisy boson sampling.
In the context of random circuit sampling, Fourierâ€“Walsh expansion played a role in Boixo et al. , Gao and Duan [ref]6, Kalai  ,
and Aharonov et al. . A basic insight in the analysis of Boolean functions is the relevance of the noise operator TÏsubscriptğ‘‡ğœŒT_{\rho}, where ÏğœŒ\rho is a real number, 0â‰¤Ïâ‰¤10ğœŒ10\leq\rho\leq 1, defined as follows. Readout errors, namely, reading with probability qğ‘q a qubit as â€œ0â€ when it is in fact â€œ1â€ and vice versa, directly correspond to the noise operator T(1âˆ’2â€‹q)subscriptğ‘‡12ğ‘T_{(1-2q)}. When the probability distribution described by a random circuit Cğ¶C on nğ‘›n qubits is given by the function ğ’«Câ€‹(x)subscriptğ’«ğ¶ğ‘¥{\cal P}_{C}(x), one ingredient of our analysis is finding the best fit to the noisy data of the form where s,qğ‘ ğ‘s,q are real numbers, 0â‰¤sâ‰¤10ğ‘ 10\leq s\leq 1 and 0â‰¤qâ‰¤1/20ğ‘120\leq q\leq 1/2. As it turned out (and can be anticipated from theoretical works  ), the value of qğ‘q may reflect not only the simple connection with readout errors but also a subtle effect of gate errors. We will refer to the value of qğ‘q that best fits the data as the â€œeffective readout error.â€ The effect of gate errors towards larger effective readout errors is witnessed in data coming from Googleâ€™s simulator but not in the samples of the Google quantum supremacy experiment. Here is a brief summary of this paper. Section 2 provides background on Fourierâ€“Walsh analysis and on the Google quantum supremacy experiment . Section 3 describes the Fourierâ€“Walsh distributions coming from random circuit sampling. Section 4 develops statistical estimates that refine the â„±Xâ€‹Eâ€‹Bsubscriptâ„±ğ‘‹ğ¸ğµ{\cal F}_{XEB} estimate (and related estimates) to study the Fourier behavior. Section 5 applies these estimates to study the samples of the Google experiment as well as samples from simulations. Of special interest to us is the effect of gate errors on the Fourierâ€“Walsh coefficients. Section 6 studies fidelity estimators. We extend some of our analysis from  to data coming from simulations of noisy quantum circuits and we concentrate on the estimators based on readout errors introduced in Section 6 of  which are related to the Fourierâ€“Walsh behavior. Section 7 concludes.
